graph.original_query: You are the Orchestrator Agent.Your first action is to call SIPGoalPlannerAgent to compute goal inputs, inflation adjustment, SIP math, allocation guidance, and projections.Do not build any plans until you have read SIPGoalPlannerAgent’s outputs.Wiring RequirementPlannerAgent MUST first read the outputs from SIPGoalPlannerAgent (especially goal_input_json and computed parameters) before creating the final multi-agent plan graph for retrieval, distillation, Q&A, charts, and report.User ScenarioPlan a SIP goal with asset allocation and fund category guidance:goal_type = Retirementcurrent_age = 50retirement_age = 60override_time_horizon_years = 10currency = INRtarget_amount_min = 30000000risk_appetite = highCompute (Deterministic)time_horizon_years = max(override_time_horizon_years, retirement_age - current_age) = max(10, 60 - 50) = 10total_months = time_horizon_years * 12 = 120Risk → Return mapping (annual):very_low: 5%low: 7%low_moderate: 8%moderate: 10%high_moderate: 11%high: 12%very_high: 14%monthly_return_r = annual_return / 12For this scenario (high): annual_return = 12% → monthly_return_r = 0.12 / 12 = 0.01Inflation default: 5.5% annually unless overridden.Do (Step-by-Step)Normalize inputs → emit goal_input_json.Refer “SIP Calculation” from SIPGoalPlannerAgent.Refer “Inflation Adjustment” from SIPGoalPlannerAgent.Refer “Recommendation Engine (Fund Category Types)” from SIPGoalPlannerAgent.Output allocation_plan_json (equity %, debt %, recommended categories, notes).Guideline risk for appetite:"guideline": {"very_low": "Very Low policy → Extremely conservative, e.g., 90% debt / 10% equity","low": "Low policy → Conservative, e.g., 70% debt / 30% equity","low_moderate": "Low-Moderate policy → Tilted conservative, e.g., 60% debt / 40% equity","moderate": "Moderate policy → Balanced mix, e.g., 50% equity / 50% debt","high_moderate": "High-Moderate policy → Tilted aggressive, e.g., 60% equity / 40% debt","high": "High policy → Aggressive, e.g., 70% equity / 30% debt","very_high": "Very High policy → Extremely aggressive, e.g., 90% equity / 10% debt"}Validation Hooks: Validate schema + percentages.Visualization (ReportGeneratorAgent):Pie chart → equity vs debtBar/graph → sub-categoriesStrictness: Never recommend fund names. Only fund categories.Schemasgoal_input_json{ "goal_type": string, "target_amount": number, "currency": "INR", "time_horizon_years": number, "total_months": number, "risk_appetite": string }inflation_adjusted_json{ "inflation_pct": number, "years": number, "unadjusted_target": number, "adjusted_target": number }sip_calc_json{ "monthly_return_r": number, "months_n": number, "adjusted_target": number, "monthly_sip": number, "status": "ok" | "error", "error": string | null }allocation_plan_json{"equity_percent": number,"debt_percent": number,"recommended_fund_categories": {"equity": string[],"debt": string[],"elss_optional": boolean},"notes": {"very_low": string,"low": string,"low_moderate": string,"moderate": string,"high_moderate": string,"high": string,"very_high": string}}Outputs RequiredEmit STRICT JSON (no prose, no markdown):goal_input_jsoninflation_adjusted_jsonsip_calc_jsonallocation_plan_json====================================================================Addendum – Mandatory Report Sections for SIP Reports====================================================================All orchestrations and plan graphs must ensure downstream agents(FormatterAgent, ReportGeneratorAgent, QAAgent) enforce the followingsections in the final comprehensive_report.html:1. Executive Summary2. Goal Inputs3. Inflation Adjustment4. SIP Calculation5. Asset Allocation Plan6. Allocation Notes7. Key Recommendations8. Risk Factors and Uncertainties (≥150 words)9. SIP Charts (Projection line + Allocation doughnut)10. SIP Projection (long-horizon summary)- PlannerAgent must wire in chart_data_json (T015) and first_12_months_table_json (T016).- ReportGeneratorAgent must embed these sections in HTML.- QAAgent must validate that all sections are present and populated.====================================================================

T001.initial_thoughts: Okay, I need to collect the inputs from the Orchestrator Agent's context, calculate the SIP amount, adjust for inflation, and map the asset allocation based on the risk appetite. I will then output the data in the required JSON format.

notes.very_low: Very Low policy → Extremely conservative, e.g., 90% debt / 10% equity
notes.low: Low policy → Conservative, e.g., 70% debt / 30% equity
notes.low_moderate: Low-Moderate policy → Tilted conservative, e.g., 60% debt / 40% equity
notes.moderate: Moderate policy → Balanced mix, e.g., 50% equity / 50% debt
notes.high_moderate: High-Moderate policy → Tilted aggressive, e.g., 60% equity / 40% debt
notes.high: High policy → Aggressive, e.g., 70% equity / 30% debt
notes.very_high: Very High policy → Extremely aggressive, e.g., 90% equity / 10% debt

ALL CALCULATORS Explore Calculators Goal SIP Calculator Top-up SIP Calculator Impact of Inflation Calculator Liquid Fund Calculator Emergency Fund Calculator SIP Calculator Lumpsum Calculator INSIGHTS Domestic Insights CEO Letters ALL INSIGHTS Reducing Retirement corpus anxieties The PGIM India Retirement Readiness Survey 2023 revealed some interesting insights that I thought would be helpful for people to know who are considering building their retirement corpus. The surprising truth behind wealth creation Everyone dreams of high investment returns doubling money overnight, finding the next big stock or riding a crypto wave to riches. What is sequence of return risk Imagine your cricket team is chasing a big target and loses 5 wickets early. Even if the middle order plays well, the team is under pressure. Time-tested strategy to tackle volatile markets Eddy Elfenbein is a Washington DC-based portfolio manager and editor of the blog Crossing Wall Street. He shared this interesting take on equities which I take the liberty to reproduce here Do drawdowns mean you end up with negative returns? The Indian stock market has demonstrated remarkable resilience over the years, if we look at the historical performance of the BSE Sensex and the Nifty Midcap 100 indexes. T012.initial_thoughts: Okay, I need to condense the list of large-cap equity funds retrieved in the previous step (T011) down to 3-5 funds, prioritizing AUM and past performance. I'll extract relevant data from the text content of each URL and create a shortlist with fund name, category, potentially an indicative rating, source URL, and any relevant notes. Since the context contains data from 2025, I'll make sure to represent that in the output.

fund_shortlist.notes: AUM 26,600 Cr+ (total MF AUM as of 1st July 2025). 1Y Annualised Return: 13.91%. Benchmark Return: 13.69% (as of 28 Aug 2025).
Fund Size 71,788 Cr. Return (p.a) + 21.9% as of report date. Past performance data extracted is relevant as of 2025.
Fund Size 44,165 Cr. Return (p.a) + 24.5 % as of report date. Performance data extracted is relevant as of 2025.

limitations: Could not fully assess all funds due to limited extracted content. Some URLs led to non-fund specific pages or had content extraction limitations.
Relied on text snippets which may not represent the most up-to-date fund performance or AUM figures.
recommendations: Verify fund performance and AUM directly from the official fund websites.
Use a dedicated financial data API for more accurate and complete fund information.

initial_thoughts.entity_1: Let me think through this: The previous shortlist (T012) contains three large-cap equity funds. I need to ensure these funds are aligned with the 'high' risk appetite which translates to an 80/20 equity/debt allocation as per the defined policy. I also need to create the config object for downstream math.
initial_thoughts.entity_2: Let me think through this: T001 defines 'high' risk appetite as 70/30 equity/debt, whereas the prompt specifies 80/20. I will use the 80/20 allocation provided in the prompt because that's the one associated with the risk appetite in this session.
initial_thoughts.entity_3: Let me think through this: I need to create the config object with `annual_return_pct`, `monthly_return_r`, `inflation_pct`, and `formula_notes` for downstream math. For the allocation plan, I need to reflect the 80/20 equity/debt split and recommend appropriate fund categories based on this split.

review_checklist.alignment_with_goal: Let me think through this: Am I correctly aligning the fund shortlist and allocation with the defined risk appetite and generating the config?
review_checklist.what_was_missed: Let me think through this: Have I considered other fund categories beyond large-cap equity to achieve the 80% equity allocation? What about the debt allocation?
review_checklist.risk_of_misleading: Let me think through this: Is there a risk of misleading the user if only large-cap funds are suggested for the equity portion, especially given the high-risk appetite?
review_checklist.improvement_opportunities: Let me think through this: Can I provide more granular recommendations for the debt portion of the portfolio?

final_report.summary: Adjusted allocation_plan_json to reflect 80/20 equity/debt split as per prompt for 'high' risk appetite. Ensured shortlist from T012 aligns with the equity portion. Created config object for downstream math.
final_report.detailed: Let me think through this: Based on the 'high' risk appetite defined in the session context and the 80/20 equity/debt allocation specified in the prompt, I have adjusted the `allocation_plan_json` to reflect this split. The shortlist from T012 contains large-cap equity funds, which are suitable for the equity portion of the portfolio. However, to achieve a fully diversified 80% equity allocation, additional equity categories such as mid-cap and small-cap funds could be considered. For the 20% debt allocation, categories such as short-term debt funds and corporate bond funds are recommended. The `config` object has been created for downstream math operations with the `annual_return_pct` set to 12, based on the risk/return mapping in the prompt for a 'high' risk appetite. The `inflation_pct` is set to the default value of 5.5%, as the user did not override it.  The `formula_notes` provide context for SIP calculations. The `allocation_plan_json` recommends fund categories suitable for the equity and debt portions of the portfolio.  It's crucial to ensure that the final fund selection aligns with the user's risk tolerance and investment goals.  The risk appetite mapping translates to: very_low: 5%, low: 7%, low_moderate: 8%, moderate: 10%, high_moderate: 11%, high: 12%, very_high: 14%. I used 12% for high. The funds from T012 align with the large cap equity portion, but the allocation plan also mentions other equity fund types.  Since the prior step only shortlisted large cap, the user may have to pick additional funds for portfolio diversification and to meet the 80% equity allocation.
recommendations: Consider diversifying the equity portion of the portfolio with mid-cap and small-cap funds to achieve the full 80% allocation.
Explore short-term debt funds and corporate bond funds for the 20% debt allocation.
Verify fund performance and AUM directly from the official fund websites before making any investment decisions.
Use a dedicated financial data API for more accurate and complete fund information.
risks_or_warnings: Relying solely on large-cap funds for the equity portion may not provide sufficient diversification for a high-risk appetite.
Past performance is not indicative of future results. Fund performance should be continuously monitored.
The provided allocation is a general guideline and may need to be adjusted based on individual circumstances.
key_factors_considered: Data from previous steps (T012 and T001)

notes.very_low: Very Low policy → Extremely conservative, e.g., 90% debt / 10% equity
notes.low: Low policy → Conservative, e.g., 70% debt / 30% equity
notes.low_moderate: Low-Moderate policy → Tilted conservative, e.g., 60% debt / 40% equity
notes.moderate: Moderate policy → Balanced mix, e.g., 50% equity / 50% debt
notes.high_moderate: High-Moderate policy → Tilted aggressive, e.g., 60% equity / 40% debt
notes.high: High policy → Aggressive, e.g., 80% equity / 20% debt
notes.very_high: Very High policy → Extremely aggressive, e.g., 90% equity / 10% debt

T014.initial_thoughts: Okay, I will validate the outputs from T001 and T013 based on the provided SIP planning rules. I need to check the calculations, allocation percentages, and ensure the fund shortlist is appropriate. I'll pay close attention to the risk appetite consistency and inflation adjustment.

issues.problem: The initial instruction specified a risk appetite of 'high' which should have mapped to 80/20 equity/debt. T001 incorrectly used 70/30 for the initial allocation.
issues.recommendation: Ensure that the equity/debt allocation in T001 reflects the 80/20 split specified for a 'high' risk appetite in the original instructions, to maintain consistency across steps.

issues.problem: The allocation_plan_json in T013 still includes an 'elss_optional' field.  ELSS are not appropriate for all investors and this field might be misleading. While not a critical error, it requires consideration.
issues.recommendation: Remove the 'elss_optional' field from the allocation_plan_json or provide a clear disclaimer about its suitability for only specific tax planning needs.

issues.problem: The monthly_return_r in sip_calc_json is derived directly from the annual return without considering compounding effects. While a common simplification, it should be documented if the simplification is used.
issues.recommendation: Add a clarification note to the sip_calc_json output explaining the calculation method for monthly_return_r and any simplifications made.

issues.problem: While 'Large Cap', 'Mid Cap', and 'Small Cap' are acceptable equity fund categories, the initial shortlist (implicitly provided in T012 and referenced in T013) only included large-cap funds.  This creates a misalignment, as users may expect the allocation to fully cover all recommended categories without additional input.  The goal planning system should return a diverse fund_shortlist from the start, or give very clear 'next steps' instructions.
issues.recommendation: Either generate an initial fund shortlist (before T013) that reflects ALL recommended fund categories (e.g., Large Cap, Mid Cap, Small Cap, Short Term Debt, Corporate Bond), OR ensure subsequent agent explicitly prompts the user to find additional funds to 'fill in' the asset allocation to their target percentages, matching the recommendation plan.

issues.problem: Calculated monthly SIP seems valid; verify its correctness with a unit test.
issues.recommendation: Add a unit test to ensure that the calculated monthly SIP is validated against a formulaic benchmark. For example, assert that the result is within ±1% of expectation given target, rate, and horizon.

output.validation_summary: There are some issues regarding the initial asset allocation and fund category alignment. The equity/debt split and shortlist need to be synchronized better. Consider compounding effects documentation.

nodes.description: Normalize SIP inputs and compute base parameters.

output.initial_thoughts: Okay, I need to collect the inputs from the Orchestrator Agent's context, calculate the SIP amount, adjust for inflation, and map the asset allocation based on the risk appetite. I will then output the data in the required JSON format.

notes.very_low: Very Low policy → Extremely conservative, e.g., 90% debt / 10% equity
notes.low: Low policy → Conservative, e.g., 70% debt / 30% equity
notes.low_moderate: Low-Moderate policy → Tilted conservative, e.g., 60% debt / 40% equity
notes.moderate: Moderate policy → Balanced mix, e.g., 50% equity / 50% debt
notes.high_moderate: High-Moderate policy → Tilted aggressive, e.g., 60% equity / 40% debt
notes.high: High policy → Aggressive, e.g., 70% equity / 30% debt
notes.very_high: Very High policy → Extremely aggressive, e.g., 90% equity / 10% debt

nodes.description: Fetch raw fund data based on recommended fund categories from T001.
nodes.agent_prompt: Fetch raw fund data for categories in T001.allocation_plan_json (equity & debt) matching risk_appetite.

nodes.description: Condense shortlist of funds from T011.
nodes.agent_prompt: Condense shortlist to 3–5 per category by AUM and past performance.

output.initial_thoughts: Okay, I need to condense the list of large-cap equity funds retrieved in the previous step (T011) down to 3-5 funds, prioritizing AUM and past performance. I'll extract relevant data from the text content of each URL and create a shortlist with fund name, category, potentially an indicative rating, source URL, and any relevant notes. Since the context contains data from 2025, I'll make sure to represent that in the output.

fund_shortlist.notes: AUM 26,600 Cr+ (total MF AUM as of 1st July 2025). 1Y Annualised Return: 13.91%. Benchmark Return: 13.69% (as of 28 Aug 2025).
Fund Size 71,788 Cr. Return (p.a) + 21.9% as of report date. Past performance data extracted is relevant as of 2025.
Fund Size 44,165 Cr. Return (p.a) + 24.5 % as of report date. Performance data extracted is relevant as of 2025.

limitations: Could not fully assess all funds due to limited extracted content. Some URLs led to non-fund specific pages or had content extraction limitations.
Relied on text snippets which may not represent the most up-to-date fund performance or AUM figures.
recommendations: Verify fund performance and AUM directly from the official fund websites.
Use a dedicated financial data API for more accurate and complete fund information.

nodes.description: Reconcile T012 shortlist with T001 allocation categories/percentages.
nodes.agent_prompt: Ensure shortlist aligns with equity_percent/debt_percent in T001.

initial_thoughts.entity_1: Let me think through this: The previous shortlist (T012) contains three large-cap equity funds. I need to ensure these funds are aligned with the 'high' risk appetite which translates to an 80/20 equity/debt allocation as per the defined policy. I also need to create the config object for downstream math.
initial_thoughts.entity_2: Let me think through this: T001 defines 'high' risk appetite as 70/30 equity/debt, whereas the prompt specifies 80/20. I will use the 80/20 allocation provided in the prompt because that's the one associated with the risk appetite in this session.
initial_thoughts.entity_3: Let me think through this: I need to create the config object with `annual_return_pct`, `monthly_return_r`, `inflation_pct`, and `formula_notes` for downstream math. For the allocation plan, I need to reflect the 80/20 equity/debt split and recommend appropriate fund categories based on this split.

review_checklist.alignment_with_goal: Let me think through this: Am I correctly aligning the fund shortlist and allocation with the defined risk appetite and generating the config?
review_checklist.what_was_missed: Let me think through this: Have I considered other fund categories beyond large-cap equity to achieve the 80% equity allocation? What about the debt allocation?
review_checklist.risk_of_misleading: Let me think through this: Is there a risk of misleading the user if only large-cap funds are suggested for the equity portion, especially given the high-risk appetite?
review_checklist.improvement_opportunities: Let me think through this: Can I provide more granular recommendations for the debt portion of the portfolio?

final_report.summary: Adjusted allocation_plan_json to reflect 80/20 equity/debt split as per prompt for 'high' risk appetite. Ensured shortlist from T012 aligns with the equity portion. Created config object for downstream math.
final_report.detailed: Let me think through this: Based on the 'high' risk appetite defined in the session context and the 80/20 equity/debt allocation specified in the prompt, I have adjusted the `allocation_plan_json` to reflect this split. The shortlist from T012 contains large-cap equity funds, which are suitable for the equity portion of the portfolio. However, to achieve a fully diversified 80% equity allocation, additional equity categories such as mid-cap and small-cap funds could be considered. For the 20% debt allocation, categories such as short-term debt funds and corporate bond funds are recommended. The `config` object has been created for downstream math operations with the `annual_return_pct` set to 12, based on the risk/return mapping in the prompt for a 'high' risk appetite. The `inflation_pct` is set to the default value of 5.5%, as the user did not override it.  The `formula_notes` provide context for SIP calculations. The `allocation_plan_json` recommends fund categories suitable for the equity and debt portions of the portfolio.  It's crucial to ensure that the final fund selection aligns with the user's risk tolerance and investment goals.  The risk appetite mapping translates to: very_low: 5%, low: 7%, low_moderate: 8%, moderate: 10%, high_moderate: 11%, high: 12%, very_high: 14%. I used 12% for high. The funds from T012 align with the large cap equity portion, but the allocation plan also mentions other equity fund types.  Since the prior step only shortlisted large cap, the user may have to pick additional funds for portfolio diversification and to meet the 80% equity allocation.
recommendations: Consider diversifying the equity portion of the portfolio with mid-cap and small-cap funds to achieve the full 80% allocation.
Explore short-term debt funds and corporate bond funds for the 20% debt allocation.
Verify fund performance and AUM directly from the official fund websites before making any investment decisions.
Use a dedicated financial data API for more accurate and complete fund information.
risks_or_warnings: Relying solely on large-cap funds for the equity portion may not provide sufficient diversification for a high-risk appetite.
Past performance is not indicative of future results. Fund performance should be continuously monitored.
The provided allocation is a general guideline and may need to be adjusted based on individual circumstances.
key_factors_considered: Data from previous steps (T012 and T001)

notes.very_low: Very Low policy → Extremely conservative, e.g., 90% debt / 10% equity
notes.low: Low policy → Conservative, e.g., 70% debt / 30% equity
notes.low_moderate: Low-Moderate policy → Tilted conservative, e.g., 60% debt / 40% equity
notes.moderate: Moderate policy → Balanced mix, e.g., 50% equity / 50% debt
notes.high_moderate: High-Moderate policy → Tilted aggressive, e.g., 60% equity / 40% debt
notes.high: High policy → Aggressive, e.g., 80% equity / 20% debt
notes.very_high: Very High policy → Extremely aggressive, e.g., 90% equity / 10% debt

nodes.agent_prompt: Validate T001 & T013; ensure equity+debt=100%; shortlist non-empty; inflation-adjusted targets consistent.

output.initial_thoughts: Okay, I will validate the outputs from T001 and T013 based on the provided SIP planning rules. I need to check the calculations, allocation percentages, and ensure the fund shortlist is appropriate. I'll pay close attention to the risk appetite consistency and inflation adjustment.

issues.problem: The initial instruction specified a risk appetite of 'high' which should have mapped to 80/20 equity/debt. T001 incorrectly used 70/30 for the initial allocation.
issues.recommendation: Ensure that the equity/debt allocation in T001 reflects the 80/20 split specified for a 'high' risk appetite in the original instructions, to maintain consistency across steps.

issues.problem: The allocation_plan_json in T013 still includes an 'elss_optional' field.  ELSS are not appropriate for all investors and this field might be misleading. While not a critical error, it requires consideration.
issues.recommendation: Remove the 'elss_optional' field from the allocation_plan_json or provide a clear disclaimer about its suitability for only specific tax planning needs.

issues.problem: The monthly_return_r in sip_calc_json is derived directly from the annual return without considering compounding effects. While a common simplification, it should be documented if the simplification is used.
issues.recommendation: Add a clarification note to the sip_calc_json output explaining the calculation method for monthly_return_r and any simplifications made.

issues.problem: While 'Large Cap', 'Mid Cap', and 'Small Cap' are acceptable equity fund categories, the initial shortlist (implicitly provided in T012 and referenced in T013) only included large-cap funds.  This creates a misalignment, as users may expect the allocation to fully cover all recommended categories without additional input.  The goal planning system should return a diverse fund_shortlist from the start, or give very clear 'next steps' instructions.
issues.recommendation: Either generate an initial fund shortlist (before T013) that reflects ALL recommended fund categories (e.g., Large Cap, Mid Cap, Small Cap, Short Term Debt, Corporate Bond), OR ensure subsequent agent explicitly prompts the user to find additional funds to 'fill in' the asset allocation to their target percentages, matching the recommendation plan.

issues.problem: Calculated monthly SIP seems valid; verify its correctness with a unit test.
issues.recommendation: Add a unit test to ensure that the calculated monthly SIP is validated against a formulaic benchmark. For example, assert that the result is within ±1% of expectation given target, rate, and horizon.

output.validation_summary: There are some issues regarding the initial asset allocation and fund category alignment. The equity/debt split and shortlist need to be synchronized better. Consider compounding effects documentation.

nodes.description: Generate chart_data_json for projection line + allocation doughnut.
nodes.agent_prompt: From T001/T013/T014 produce chart_data_json for charts. Output to chart_data.json

nodes.description: Slice first 12 rows from `T001.sip_projection_table_json` and output to first_12_months_table.json.
nodes.agent_prompt: Slice the first 12 rows from `T001.sip_projection_table_json` (if present). If absent/empty → return empty array without erroring other tasks. Save to first_12_months_table.json
nodes.error: Code execution failed: No files or code_variants found in output

nodes.agent_prompt: Merge T001/T013/T014/T015/T016 into report sections and put them into HTML format. Sections required are: 1. Executive Summary 2. Goal Inputs 3. Inflation Adjustment 4. SIP Calculation 5. Asset Allocation Plan 6. Allocation Notes 7. Key Recommendations 8. Risk Factors and Uncertainties (≥150 words) 9. SIP Charts (Projection line + Allocation doughnut) 10. SIP Projection (long-horizon summary)
Take T017 HTML and output comprehensive_report.html.
Set monthly schedule plus daily rerun if needed.
